On April 18, a resident of Fakirpara Road under Parnasree PS lodged a complaint that sometime in the recent past, a woman working as an attendant in her home had stolen gold ornaments worth nearly Rs 6 lakh, plus at least Rs 8,000-10,000 in cash. Incidentally, the woman had only begun working at the complainant’s residence on April 8.  
The attendant Sampa Roy, a resident of Sardar Para in neighbouring Barisha, was promptly apprehended early on the morning of the very next day, and based on her statement, the major portion of the stolen items was recovered from Haridevpur. In fact, the stolen cash was worth not Rs 10,000 but over Rs 24,000. 
The accused has been remanded to police custody until April 22 by the ACJM, Alipore.

CAPTIONS:
Suspicious Business!
‘Urgent business discussion’. This was the bait used to lure a 60-year-old resident of the Girish Park PS area to a hotel in Sarat Bose Road. What happened next is our story for today.
On April 24, Ballygunge PS received a letter of complaint from the Girish Park resident, alleging that for the past few days, he had been receiving WhatsApp calls from unknown women who wanted to meet him in a hotel for what they described as an urgent business discussion. 
On April 23, he met two women near a well-known dhaba in south Kolkata, and they convinced him to book a room in a hotel on Sarat Bose Road. After checking in at about 2.00 pm, they offered the complainant a drink which he accepted, but passed out soon after consuming. When he woke up nearly six hours later, he found the two women were missing, as were his gold neck chain and silver bracelet. 
Before leaving, they had completely erased the WhatsApp chat history from his mobile. What’s more, we found that they had used photocopies of forged Aadhar cards during check-in, and hadn’t provided any contact numbers. Apparently, we had no way of tracing them, or so they thought.
Of course, they were wrong. Apart from CCTV footage of the location and technological data from the complainant’s mobile, we also gathered information from nodal officers of hospitality and dating apps. Based on all of this, we used both technological surveillance and our source network to track down and arrest Ankita Guha (26) on April 28 from the Netajinagar PS area, as the prime accused in the case. 
Based on her statement, her co-accused Moumita Chakraborty (26) was arrested from her residence in Nadia district’s Kotwali Krishnanagar PS area on the morning of April 30. The stolen chain and bracelet were recovered from a jewellery shop in Baghajatin. 
Our investigation has revealed that the two are habitual offenders, who would look for potential victims on dating and wedding apps. After meeting the victims, they would offer drinks laced with powerful sedatives and, once the victim was unconscious, steal their expensive belongings. They always used fake SIM and identity cards to evade capture, but the game had to end somewhere. 
The investigation is still on, and both accused are in police custody until May 4.

Talked into Trouble!
All it took was 20 minutes for Siddhartha Sarkar to lose Rs 9.40 lakh. In cash. From inside a moving bus. And he didn’t even realise the loss until he had got off the bus. Worse still, the money belonged to the silver business in which he was an employee.
The incident, which occurred on June 11, was reported to Jorasanko PS by the business owner, who stated that Siddhartha had boarded a bus from Beadon Street to the MG Road-Rabindra Sarani crossing, when he was befriended by two women. The younger of the two engaged Siddhartha in conversation, and he apparently became so engrossed that he didn’t notice what the older woman was doing. It was only once he got off the bus that he realised that his bag felt lighter. 
He may not have noticed what she was doing, but the team from our Detective Department’s Watch Section did, once they had scoured through hours and hours of footage from more than 40 CCTV cameras covering the entire stretch that Siddhartha travelled that day. It became obvious that the older woman had extracted the money from Siddhartha's bag as he was deep in conversation, wrapped it in her scarf, and got off the bus. Also obviously, Siddhartha had been watched and targeted. 
But most of the footage was so grainy that our team struggled to find a clear image that would identify the women. In the end, though, the blurred images were enough for the team's source network to locate Sova Rajput (50) and Hansa Prem Solanki (35), both originally from the Kalupur area of Ahmedabad and currently residents of Rishra, Hooghly. Both were later arrested from the Hooghly PS area, and confessed to the theft. Based on their statements, cash worth Rs 9,03,000 has been recovered so far. Further investigation continues.

Quest for Gold!
Amount of gold jewellery -- 7 kg 805 gram; price -- a little over Rs 5 crore 20 lakh. This was what a gold merchant from Titagarh carried to a hotel in Kolkata's Shakespeare Sarani police station area, apparently to meet a customer named Mithu, who would hand over gold bars in exchange for the jewellery. The exchange happened as decided, but when the businessman went back to his shop, he realised that the 'customer' had given him fake gold bars, and decamped with the real gold jewellery.
The incident happened on July 17, after which the businessman lodged a complaint with Shakespeare Sarani PS. Visiting the spot, our investigators examined CCTV footage and identified 'Mithu'. They also saw that Mithu, a Bangladeshi national, clearly had an associate waiting outside the hotel on the day of the incident, and the two fled together with the jewellery. With a little help from sources, this accomplice was identified as Jitan Pal, a goldsmith in the Bowbazar area.
The team from Shakespeare Sarani PS then picked up Jitan from the Muchipara PS area and based on his statement, arrested Uttam Pal and another Bangladeshi national Gautam Chandra Saha from the same area. Jitan then led the investigators to Ramesh Behera's residence, once again in the same area, and 5 kg 684 gram of jewellery was recovered from there.

The case was registered on June 6 the basis of a letter from a resident of New CIT Road under Bowbazar PS, and the report of Sergeant Santanu Gain of Cyber PS at Lalbazar.

Finally, the seeming mastermind behind the entire operation, Atish Dipankar Dutta (44), was arrested from the Sreebhumi area under Lake Town PS today.
A number of mobile handsets, electronic gadgets, forged bank and company documents and other articles have been seized from the accused.
